text: The wind finally stops. The snow stops with it. Outside the North Gate, only the crackle of dying embers remains—and the soldiers’ disbelieving breaths.
The barrier’s blue light no longer fractures. It hums like a string drawn tight again, steady against the city wall.
The black mist left behind by the Demon King scatters in the fading wind, revealing blasted snow and shattered stone—like a nightmare torn into pieces.
I kneel in the snow, my hands still shaking. My fingers find warmth—not fire, but her body heat.
Alicia lies in my arms, half her armor shattered, silver hair damp with snow. Her eyes are closed—but she is breathing.
The breaths are shallow—but not fading. More like someone finally allowing herself to sleep.
“Alicia…?”
Her lashes flutter, as if confirming the voice she hears isn’t a dream.
“I heard you.”
“Heard what?”
“You said you’d wait for me.”
She lifts her hand weakly, fingers catching my sleeve like a line pulling her back.
“This time… I wasn’t alone.”
Someone runs toward us, cloak whipping snow into the air.
Lucia rushes over. Seeing Alicia alive drains the strength from her knees.
“Master… you’re here… you’re really here…”
Alicia glances at her, voice hoarse but clear:
“Don’t cry. Not this time.”
Lucia nods fiercely, tears still falling into the snow.
Battle mages rush to inspect the barrier. Someone shouts, “We did it!” The cry echoes along the wall.
The soldiers don’t cheer. They simply stand—like men finally allowed to lower their lives from their throats.
I hold Alicia a little tighter, afraid that if I loosen my grip, time will steal her again.
“Let’s go home.”
She blinks, as if the word ‘home’ has never belonged to her.
“…Okay.”
They walk back along the snow-covered road. A pale gold line breaks at the horizon—dawn gently pried open.
Doors crack open. Faces peek out. People confirm the monster is truly gone.
At the fountain square, a child runs up, pressing a warm bag of bread into Alicia’s arms.
The child looks up, eyes bright as stars:
“You were so cool! I want to be like you!”
Alicia looks down at the steaming bread, fingers tightening slowly.
Her lips tremble between smile and break—but she smiles anyway. A real one.
“Then first… learn not to be reckless.”
The tavern door opens. The hearth still burns. Familiar wood-scent greets them.
This time, there is no countdown pressing against the air. No sense of ‘next time.’ Only real exhaustion—and real warmth.
I set her gently into a chair and rush for warm water and clean cloth.
“If you ever charge out alone again—I really will get angry!”
She hums softly, eyes closed, like she’s admitting fault.
When I finish bandaging her, I touch the ring-shaped mark beneath her collarbone. It no longer burns. No longer darkens.
It fades quietly—like it has finally lost its grip on time.
“Is it… really over?”
She opens her eyes and nods slowly.
“It’s over.”
“I don’t have to go back three days anymore.”
“And I don’t have to pretend it’s the first time meeting you.”
The room falls quiet. The hearth pops softly, like a witness.
“So what now?”
“Now… I want to learn how to live.”
“Not the world-saving kind of life.”
“The kind where I can daydream, eat, and have you complain that the soup’s too salty.”
I laugh, eyes stinging. “If you put the salt on the left side of the counter again—I’ll absolutely complain.”
She laughs too—soft, but enough to melt the winter.
“And what about me? Do I get a part in this future too?”
She ruffles Lucia’s hair, awkward but sincere. “Of course. From now on… together.”
That night, the tavern lights don’t go out early.
They finish cold bread and overdue wine beside the fire.
No one says ‘loop.’ No one says ‘next time.’
Because this time—time finally moves forward.
I place the brass die into the deepest drawer behind the counter and close it.
The die does not roll again. It rests like ordinary metal.
Snow falls lightly outside—like a blessing.
Half-asleep in her chair, she murmurs softly:
“Tomorrow… I think I’ll try being the innkeeper’s wife.”
“You sure? You’ll scare off the customers.”
“Then I’ll keep just one.”
She falls asleep mid-sentence, forehead resting gently against the table—safe at last.
I stay beside her, pulling her cloak up over her shoulders.
The firelight on her face no longer looks like snow. No longer like steel.
It looks like home.

event.message:
The world did not reset.

This time,
tomorrow will truly arrive.

The die is silent.
Time moves forward.

—— TRUE END ——
